questions.text: Salt and pepper fundus is seen in all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tuberculosis The retina can indirectly be involved with ocular tuberculosis due to an associated choroiditis , but direct retinal involvement is rare. In the event of primary retinal involvement, the presentation is either a presumed tubercular retinal vasculitis or Eales' disease , an associated vasculitis thought to represent a hypersensitivity reaction to tuberculosis.

Highyeild:

Veins are more commonly affected than arteries in tubercular retinal vasculitis, and peripheral capillary occlusion is present.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Rubella Option: B. Syphilis - yes, the correct option Option: C. Refsum's disease - yes, the correct option

Extraedge:

Vitritis, retinal hemorrhages, and neovascularization are also regularly associated. Periphlebitis is often present in Eales' disease, but there is no other evidence of intraocular inflammation. Additionally, Eales' disease is characterized by peripheral non-perfusion and ischemia, neovascularization, and recurrent vitreous hemorrhage.

Solution:

Foveal Detachment The retinal pigment epithelium can usually maintain adhesion with the overlying neurosensory retina through various mechanisms. Foveal detachment and macular break resolution result from the release or weakening of vitreous traction on the fovea. Reattachment of the foveal retina preserves fair to good visual acuity.

Highyeild:

Surgical intervention is contraindicated in eyes in which foveal detachment flattens and develops a pseudo-operculum and when a posterior vitreous detachment develops in an eye with a stage 2 macular break.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. These mechanisms include active transport of subretinal fluid and interdigitation of outer segments and the retinal pigment epithelium microvilli. Option: C. With retinal detachment , these mechanisms are overwhelmed, separating the neurosensory (inner layers) retina from the retinal pigment epithelial layer. Option: D. Retinal detachment occurs when subretinal fluid accumulates between the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. This process can occur in three ways. One mechanism involves a break in the retina, allowing the vitreous to enter the subretinal space directly. This is known as a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment . Rhegmatogenous retinal detachments are often due to retinal tears associated with posterior vitreous detachment or trauma.

Extraedge:

Careful biomicroscopic vitreous examination and microperimetry with the scanning laser ophthalmoscope are beneficial methods for adequately examining patients.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used to diagnose granular dystrophy of the cornea?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Masson trichrome Granular corneal dystrophy , Type 2 (Granular-Lattice) (GCD2), also known as combined granular-lattice corneal dystrophy or Avellino corneal dystrophy , occurs in the first decade, maybe as early as three years of age and the condition is generally progressive. The genetic locus is 5q31, and the gene involved is TGFB1. Inheritance is autosomal dominant. Signs include: Subtle superficial stromal tiny whitish dots are initial lesions. The next lesions are ring or stellate-shaped snowflake stromal opacities between the superficial and mid-stroma. Lattice Lines In deeper cornea may be seen in some patients. Typically, these lines are located deeper than the snowflake stromal opacity.

Highyeild:

Superficial, translucent, flattened breadcrumb opacities are seen in the final stages, which may coalesce in the anterior stroma. Symptoms include: Vision decreases with age as the central visual axis becomes affected. Pain and ocular discomfort may accompany mild corneal erosions. Assessed by using stains like Masson.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: A. Colloidal iron Option: B. Congo red Option:C.PAS Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) Staining Gastric signet ring cell carcinoma histopathology, PAS stain Esophageal candidiasis, PAS stain Liver in glycogen storage disease, PAS stain

Extraedge:

Masson's trichrome staining is also widely used to study muscular pathologies (muscular dystrophy), cardiac pathologies (infarct), hepatic pathologies (cirrhosis), or kidney pathologies (glomerular fibrosis). It can also detect and analyze tumors on hepatic and kidney biopsies.

questions.text: A 7-year-old presents with left exotropia; the right eye has 6/6 vision with normal fundus. The left eye has only closed hand movements, subretinal yellow exudates, retinal detachment, and telangiectatic vessels. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coat’s disease Coats disease is a telangiectatic neovascular disease of the retina of unknown etiology that frequently affects the unilateral eyes of young males. Coats disease is usually characterized by the unilateral (95%) progressive development of abnormal vessels in the retina of the affected individuals. It’s more frequent in males (at least 3:1) than females and in patients younger than eight , even though it has been observed in infants and older patients.

Extraedge:

Differential Diagnosis : Leukocoria the d/dof PFV, especially anterior PFV. Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular tumor in childhood. Other d/d - congenital cataract, coat’s disease, uveitis, retinopathy of prematurity
